qas.question: The ring-necked pheasant has been introduced as what kind of bird?
Why have some species spread naturally far beyond their original ranges?

answers.text: agricultural practices created suitable new habitat

qas.question: Where have many birds established breeding populations?

answers.text: in areas to which they have been introduced by humans

context: Many bird species have established breeding populations <a2_0>in areas to which they have been introduced by humans<a2_0/>. Some of these introductions have been deliberate; the ring-necked pheasant, for example, has been introduced around the world as a <a0_0>game bird<a0_0/>. Others have been accidental, such as the establishment of wild monk parakeets in several North American cities after their escape from captivity. Some species, including cattle egret, yellow-headed caracara and galah, have spread naturally far beyond their original ranges as <a1_0>agricultural practices created suitable new habitat<a1_0/>.
